comments:

Log file is below.
That was Eclipse 3.2M1 with Mylar for 3.1 stream.

And here I thought that we were guarding against all the lazy startup dangers...

What was the effect of this, did you have to hit Stop on the progress dialog, or
kill Eclipse?  Did Mylar come up properly after restart?  Also, I'm curious
about what's forcing you to use 3.2M1 (Subclipse)?  We'll only be able to
support the latest milestone of 3.2 because of the cost of merging, but
hopefully initialization order could fix this issue for the 3.1 stream.

(In reply to comment #1)
> And here I thought that we were guarding against all the lazy startup dangers...

Apparently not all...

> What was the effect of this, did you have to hit Stop on the progress dialog, or
> kill Eclipse?  

The workbench window was gray. So I had to kill it.

> Did Mylar come up properly after restart?  

Looks like it did.

> Also, I'm curious
> about what's forcing you to use 3.2M1 (Subclipse)?  

It doesn't seem that Subclipse is actually that sensitive (turns out that my
workspace have some garage that make it worse on 3.2M2). 
However AJDT does not have update site for 3.2 stream.

> We'll only be able to
> support the latest milestone of 3.2 because of the cost of merging, but
> hopefully initialization order could fix this issue for the 3.1 stream.

Right. When 3.2M3 get out, I'll have to decide what I like more - new M3
features or convenience of getting new AJDT builds...

Eugene, I saw this happen once and will keep an eye on it.  There was no bad
behavior, since this class actually does get loaded.  Let me know if you see it
again.

Another user ran into this, scheduling for this week.


*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 115496 ***
